page.title: 17GRANDS VAUX WATER MILLS
page.content: Grands Vaux, which means big streams, was one of the most important streams of Jersey. Over the years at least ten water mills have been sited along the valley and eight of these are known to have been working at one time. These mills are first recorded in the the 13th century. Rebuilt of local stone in the 17th century, their millstones came from either France or Derbyshire. Most of the moving parts including gears, were made of wood. Most of the mills had a set of millstones for grinding wheat to make a fine white flour and a set for grinding oats for cattle feed. Most of the mills have either been knocked down or burnt down and all but one have not been used since before World War 2.
